hedline.hl1: License Plates for the Digital Highway

abstract.p: Pennsylvania puts state Web address on bottom of new license plates; photo (S)

block.p: PENNSYLVANIA is using traffic jams to generate more hits -- not fender-benders, but visits to its official site on the World Wide Web.

The state has put its Web address -- www.state.pa.us -- across the bottom of its new blue, white and yellow license plates, albeit in type small enough that only those with excellent vision or a penchant for tailgating can see it.
PENNSYLVANIA is using traffic jams to generate more hits -- not fender-benders, but visits to its official site on the World Wide Web.

The state has put its Web address -- www.state.pa.us -- across the bottom of its new blue, white and yellow license plates, albeit in type small enough that only those with excellent vision or a penchant for tailgating can see it.
By June 2002, nine million of these 72 square-inch billboards will be issued in the state's first complete plate replacement since 1976.
In introducing the new plates, Gov. Tom Ridge said, ''The old, faded yellow ones sent exactly the wrong signal.'' The right signal, he said, is to promote the state's high-technology prowess.

So far, the strategy has worked, said Anthony Haubert, a spokesman for the state Department of Transportation. ''The number of hits on our Web site has increased dramatically,'' he said. ''While it could be due to a number of reasons, we do have the feeling that the deployment generated a lot of those inquiries.''
He added that advertising the site helped to ''put the state at the forefront of technology and e-government.''

And even if the new design has received mixed reviews in the Keystone State, the idea has caught on elsewhere. In 2002, Nebraska will introduce a license plate imprinted with its own Web address: www.state.ne.us.

With several new cars promising built-in Internet access, will motorists succumb to the temptation to visit the Keystone State in cyberspace even as they cruise the Pennsylvania Turnpike in real time?
